displayed_text: Patient: Uh, there’s no penalty if I don’t, is there? Doctor: If you don’t go on-? Patient: If I do go there and don’t go on it? Where, where will I get the shots at if I um stay here? Doctor: Here. Patient: Oh, here? Doctor: Yes. In the hospital. You just, uh, or downstairs in radiation, sorry. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Yeah. They have a room that, uh, where they would do the- Patient: You can’t tell what I’m getting? Doctor: No. No. I think we’ll, we will know if you’re getting the real thing or not. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: But, you know, we don’t have a choice.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: of just the stuff. Healthcare Professional: Oh yeah. There’s you know some other areas some lymph nodes are slightly enlarged, Patient: Right. Doctor: they’ve gotten a little bit bigger. Your PSA has gone up just a little bit too. So I think… Patient: What’s a little bit? Healthcare Professional: Your last one was thirty one point seven a week ago it was twenty six. Patient: Okay. Healthcare Professional: So there’s a little bit of progression there that maybe… Doctor: It’s a movement you know. Healthcare Professional: …we’ll do something different for you. Okay. Doctor: Yeah so I’m thinking we’re always trying to not be behind. Patient: Right, right..

Patient: No. Doctor: No? Patient: No. Doctor: Then why did I bring you back? Patient: You said I have to change, huh, some treatment. Doctor: Let me see what I’ve got here. So you’ve got pain. Let’s put that there. Okay. Any other bumps or lumps that you’ve noted? Any rashes, skin changes? Patient: Uh-uh. Doctor: And have you been able to-? Any of these things come out to you? Have you already seen these labs or everything I’m going to tell you is new? Patient: You going to tell me new. Doctor: Let me see what I have. You had your bloodwork yesterday. So your white count’s normal. Huh, you’re anemic, been about the same. You’ve got normal platelets. So your iron stuff isn’t really helping, but, huh, your kidney test, liver tests, your potassium is on the low side so you take your supplement. You probably often forget one of them, one of them probably, I bet. Doctor: It’s hard to remember that second one. Blood sugar’s okay. One of your bone tests is still high, but not as high as it was last time. That doesn’t mean we’re going to do anything different. But, huh, and then your liver tests, kidney tests are normal. Huh, your testosterone says you have no testosterone. So the medicines we’ve been giving you are doing their job. Then your PSA has changed. Huh, it was twenty three months ago, twenty-eight when I saw you four weeks ago, and now it’s thirty-nine. Let’s see what we have for scans. I’ll look at your brain. Your brain looks fine. Now to this MRI. Really they don’t talk much about your bones. That’s good. Huh, let’s see. Your bone scan. Huh, did we have that last time as well? Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Just working zone. (Laughter) Doctor: How you feeling? Patient: I’ve been great. Doctor: The rest of your labs are fine, but, you know, your PSA is trickling up, four point two. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Now, in March, you were at two and a half. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And I know that we want to be as aggressive as possible with you. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: Because sometimes when your disease decides to do something, we need to quiet it down quick. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: You had a shot in June. So your next one isn’t, you know, until September. Family Member: Right. Right.

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Okay so the first thing would be to check and see uh if the cancer is still visible or invisible. In other words can we see the cancer on scan – Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - whether bone scan or CAT scan? Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: Or is it still invisible and can we not see it? Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we call that micro metastatic cancer. Patient: All right. Doctor: Has spread somewhere else, but it’s so tiny, microscopic that we cannot find it on the scans. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And in the past we did have two areas that lit up on the bone. Patient: Right.

Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: So either Xtandi or Zytiga is actually they’re both FDA approved in this space… Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …to treat folks who have progressed, albeit gently for you, a few new things and a few a little bit of a rise on the PSA, but enough to show that you need to be on something. Both equally good. Both equally have their own pot of side effects. Both equally effective in lowering the PSA and treating the cancer. Patient: Just so you know… Doctor: Okay. Patient: …of all the treatments I’ve had… Doctor: Yep. Patient: …I have never had any side effects of anything. Doctor: Terrific, terrific. Patient: Radiation… Doctor: Yep. Yep. Patient: …the Provenge, the pheresis.

Patient: That’s different than this. Doctor: Yeah, because this this genotype that we're looking for- it does not predispose you to cancer. Patient: Okay. Doctor: This is something that's very common in the population. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We just think that these people are more likely to respond to antioxidants. Family Member: Mm. Doctor: But the, yeah, so the, I can print this out for you too, just so that you have it for your records. The testing to see if you have the hereditary risk of cancer was negative. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright, so of these options, what I think is reasonable, and what I think is not reasonable. Observation for you actually, I don't think is reasonable. You're a pretty healthy guy. You're a pretty healthy guy. And you don't have any comorbidities. You know, I would expect you to live if you didn't have prostate cancer, I would expect to live for at least another 10 years. So I think that we should do something more than observation, right? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. So this one would not be my first choice. Intermittent hormone therapy, I think if you wanted to go for a standard approach, like what everybody else is doing, I think that that is a very reasonable option. The downside is that you would be exposed to hormone therapy. And when we get to, if you ever get to this phase where you have metastatic disease where we can see your lymph nodes or see disease in the bones, you get started on hormonal hormone therapy anyways. So what usually happens in this approach is that you're getting it every six months. And, you know, maybe you get it for six months and you’re off of it for two years, maybe three years together for six months or a year, go for six months necessarily. This is certainly not a bad option. This is the standard option. This is what we consider the standard of care, like what's most widely accepted. And this could be an option now or later. You know, having talked to you before. I think what we should maybe try and do first is see if you'd be eligible and if you have this genotype for the MAP study.

Family Member: Okay. Patient: June eighteen for the blood work? Doctor: Yes, from C____ sometime that week. Patient: Yeah right. pause]] Family Member: Now are his bloodwork test results available online? Doctor: No. We don’t have it an outpatient patient portal yet. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: We have an inpatient one but you know that doesn’t apply to you. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So yeah. So now we have to do this phone and paper printout things. Which will change we are hoping sometime soon chuckles]]. Patient: Your kids done for the year? Doctor: Yeah they are.

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: But we’ll be talking to you within the next few days and seeing if we have to alter the plans at all. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: So what you think my tests might be? Doctor: Yeah. We’ll find out by tomorrow. Patient: Okay, that’ll be good. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Thank you. Doctor: You’re welcome. Patient: Nice seeing you again. Doctor: Do you have any questions? Patient: Um no. I’m I’m good.

Family Member: Why don’t we just stop it. Doctor: So go ahead and stop it for now. And we’ll restart it once we feel comfortable that there’s no bleeding and you know… Patient: Okay so I’m off the aspirin. Even the little ones? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Totally off the aspirin. Healthcare Professional: Even the baby aspirin. Family Member: And that’s what B____ said. Patient: I know. Okay. Family Member: Um. Healthcare Professional: Let me get your reports copied. Family Member: Do you mind if we, is it possible to sit in here and read through the consent? Just so we have… Doctor: That’s fine. It’s just that do you want to - are you okay with doing that? Patient: No, no, let’s take our time.

Patient: Right. Doctor: They come in, which, and you know when they looked at your picture um it really was where this was all started — that’s the problem because you can tell just by them just having to put a catheter in, that uh once your bladder gets empty and kidney functions get better. Patient: Right. Doctor: Uh yeah so those are issues we have to talk about whether or not there is any role for radiation even though that’s not going to fix the big problem. It may help you pee better. Patient: Uh hum. Family Member: Um now since the cancer has spread, that the main problem Doctor: Uh huh. Family Member: - and the prostate is enlarged. Does it make any sense to remove it? Doctor: No, we wouldn’t operate on it. We would potentially radiate it. Family Member: Okay. Patient: Yeah, I understood that it would not be removed. Family Member: Okay, so you need to advise us and…

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 2 years (1 year but less: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 2 years (1 year but less than 2 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: - have not had it as an issue. Family Member: Everybody has their issues. Doctor: It is. So every time you read that consent form it’s like you opened up a bottle of Motrin, took out the little package insert, (HCP laughing) Family Member: You know even one person Doctor: Um hum. FAM - who’s on the study said oh I had seizures – Healthcare Professional: You have to write it down. Doctor: You’re absolutely right. Yep. But I think you know whether you’re on this study or not as we talked about in the past, you, that pill is something that is a standard of care. Like I would give that whether you make it on this study or whether you choose to be on this study. Family Member: Got it. Doctor: So that’s the good part. Family Member: Now this has been approved? Doctor: Yeah. Yes. That one is approved. Healthcare Professional: The Xtandi, yes.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Is that wrong for you or you just came in rushing? Patient: No, no, it’s usually pretty good, about one forty, one fifty at the highest. So that is a little high, yeah. Doctor: Are you taking Ondansetron? That’s for nausea. Patient: Uh occasionally, not as much as I did when I was going through radiation. Doctor: So occasionally, like once a week, once a month? Patient: Uh twice a week. Family Member: You took it last night, didn’t you when you were nauseous. Patient: Oh yeah, yeah, okay, about twice a week then. And Tums. Doctor: Okay so you take the Amlodipine once a day. Patient: Yes, I do. Doctor: Baby aspirin?

Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: We think it’s probably a little bit better tolerated because we’re only giving one drug Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: than it is you know the hair loss, the nausea, the vomiting, Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: you know the numbness of the fingertips, excess tearing, you know changes in blood counts, that you’re at risk for infection, can cause liver injury, nausea, things that you feel Family Member: And is that for all chemotherapy or just this specific one that T___ has? Doctor: The neuropathies, the eye tearing are pretty specific to this drug. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But the rest of it because we’re killing dividing cells, Family Member: Uh hum. the hair loss, the drops in blood count are consistent with chemotherapy. Doctor: Yeah, we do, you know we know what we need to give you to sort of prevent the nausea when you’re getting the drug.

Family Member: That’s okay. Doctor: Okay. Patient: So um I think we should take it one step at a time and keep all our options open. So uh stay with the Xtandi and the Lupron and bring in the BET. And uh I I’m gonna be getting it from Midtown rather from here and they’ll know that? Doctor: Oh well once – what I was going to propose is that I give you the copy of the consent. If you want you can read it and uh if you’re ready to sign today you can, or we can schedule all the testing in anticipation of putting you on the study and all of that downtown and then that same day you can come in and sign the consent and do all the testing necessary. That gives you some time to think it over talk it over before signing. Patient: And you said it would just be a couple days I’d have to be there? Doctor: The two days are the long days. There are other days that you would be coming in and I just… Patient: For how long? Doctor: Well that’s what the consent will give you the exact details Patient: Okay, Yeah. Doctor: of how many times a week, but the first few weeks typically are very, what this is called is a Phase I study. So it’s an earlier setting like I said the combination really we don’t have a good handle on what to expect in terms of toxicities, what dose, etc. So one of the side effects that has been noted so far is that the platelets can drop with this medication. So that is something of course the blood counts will be monitored anyway. Besides that kidney function, liver function, all that will also be monitored and checked. You go – undergo EKG monitoring that will be hard test like and echo before you start. So there is a lot of components. One additional component is that you probably will need to do a biopsy again as part of the study. Doctor: So that’s something to think about before you say yes or no. Patient: And does platelets dropping how would that affect me physically? Doctor: Well if it gets really low then it can cause bleeding and things like that -
